justification: The article states that “Information acquisition data (e.g. eye or mouse-movement data) is dynamic,” and notes that it analyses “five eye-tracking datasets,” indicating that eye-movement recordings are the instrument used to quantify visual attention.

When describing how the construct is captured, the paper lists “eye or mouse-movement data” as examples of “Information acquisition data,” showing that mouse-movement traces serve as a measure of information-sampling behaviour.

In the effort-allocation dataset the choice involved “a 3-back working memory task” versus “a 1-back task,” indicating that different N-back levels were used as the operational measure of required cognitive effort.

justification: The paper analyses “intertemporal choices between a smaller amount of money received sooner and a larger amount of money received later,” making this two-option choice paradigm the instrument for assessing intertemporal preference.

measured_by: risky choice task (high-risk-high-reward vs. low-risk-low-reward gambles)
justification: Datasets included “risky choices between a smaller amount of money received with a higher probability and a larger amount of money received with a lower probability,” so this probabilistic-gamble task serves as the measure of risk preference.
